feedback.Physical object: Excluded — The rule is a concept, not a tangible object. Its physical form is a representation of the concept.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Included — It is a human-created logical construct with a defined syntax and function.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — It does not mimic or derive from biological systems.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — As a conceptual entity, it has no spatial immobility in the physical sense.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — Its structure is conceptual (syntax, grammar, nesting), not physically load-bearing.
feedback.Perceptible: Excluded — It is not perceived physically, but intellectually or semantically through its representation.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — It is a formal concept, not composed of matter.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — This trait is not meaningfully applicable to a conceptual entity.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Excluded — A rule is a statement of a relationship; its purpose is assigned by the system it is part of, not intrinsic to the rule itself.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — The rule itself does not generate output; it is a precondition for a result.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — It is a representation of logic, but does not act or process autonomously.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — It is a static, timeless concept and does not have a dynamic internal state.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — It is a static concept, not an interactive interface.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Excluded — It is a building block of a system, but its identity is not system-bound.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — It requires an external system to evaluate and execute it.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — It is a component, not an entire system itself, and thus not critical on its own.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — It uses symbols (`if`, `then`, `x`, `y`) to represent a logical relationship.
feedback.Communicative: Included — Its primary purpose is to communicate a conditional relationship between concepts.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Included — It is the fundamental building block of logical systems and is defined by strict logical rules.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Included — Rules can be nested within other rules and combined to form more complex systems.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Included — Its primary purpose is to guide the behavior of a system or agent based on specific conditions.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Included — It can be used to describe or reference other rules or logical systems.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — It is a timeless concept, even if it is used to describe time-based events.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Included — Its meaning and validity are dependent on the context and domain of its application.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — The concepts of formal logic and the symbols used are products of human development.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — The rules of formal logic and the standards of its use are defined by the relevant community (e.g., computer science, philosophy).
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Excluded — It does not define the identity or role of a person or group.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Included — The use of a logic rule is governed by formal proof systems and a set of shared rules.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — The concept is a fundamental unit of knowledge that can be taught and transmitted.
feedback.Visible: Included — It is presented in a visual form to be read and understood.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Excluded — This trait is more aptly described by 'Contextual abstraction' in the abstract layer.
feedback.Widely known: Included — The basic concept of 'If-Then' is a globally recognized and foundational idea.

encoding_notes: This encoding captures the If-Then Logic Rule as a purely abstract, human-created conceptual entity. It is defined by its symbolic, logical, and social properties, and its core function is to guide behavior, a key distinction from other abstract entities. The resulting code reflects its lack of physical and functional traits, with high density in the abstract and social layers.
